DOC.HEAD: Delay Possible in Mideast Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: A senior Israeli diplomat is beginning preparations today for an opening round of Mideast peace talks here next month, but there is growing doubt the U.S.-sponsored meetings will get off the ground without delay. Diplomatic sources cited moves by the Palestine Liberation Organization as the reason it is no longer certain the talks, to be hosted by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, will be held. Still, Israeli cabinet secretary Eliakim Rubinstein, who played a leading role in negotiations that led to the 1979 Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty, was sent here Sunday from Jerusalem. He is meeting at the State Department with Dennis Ross, head of the State Department's policy planning staff and Baker's closest adviser on the Middle East, and with Richard Haass and other National Security Council staffers. Ross broke away from Baker's trip to Europe last week to prepare for the meeting with Rubinstein. Egypt, meanwhile, is sending no special representative from Cairo to make preparations. Ambassador Sayed el Reedy is available, as needed. The three-way talks Baker hopes to have with Foreign Ministers Moshe Arens of Israel and Esmat Abdel Meguid of Egypt would be the first step toward Palestinian elections on the Israeli-held West Bank and in Gaza. Both Israel and Egypt have agreed to the meeting, reserving some issues to be settled once Arad and Meguid saw Baker. But since the State Department announced Egypt's qualified acceptance 12 days ago, problems have arisen between the Arab country and the PLO. They raise questions whether Egypt would be speaking for Yasser Arafat's organization. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir assured President Bush and Baker on a visit here in mid-November that he was committed to his plan for elections among the 1.4 million Palestinian Arabs in the territories. The idea is to choose negotiators to work out limited self-rule with Israel, a plan that has the support of the Bush administration but is challenged by the PLO as a ploy to prevent establishment of a Palestinian state. When Egypt agreed to Baker's proposal for a planning meeting here in January it registered some reservations, as Israel had done earlier. They were to be taken up at the meeting. Essentially, Egypt reserved the right to promote a role for the PLO in selecting a Palestinian delegation that would hold pre-election talks with Israel in Cairo. Israel, meanwhile, reserved the right to try to exclude the PLO from having any meaningful role. On Dec. 6, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, announced that Egypt had accepted Baker's proposal. She called it a ``step forward'' in the peace process. But the PLO asserted a more direct role by giving its qualified acceptance to Robert Pelletreau Jr., the U.S. ambassador to Tunisia who has been the U.S. contact with the PLO since a dialogue was opened a year ago. And then Arafat sent a private letter to Bush indicating his willingness to make peace. While the president did not reply, the opening of a PLO channel to the White House serves to undercut the idea that the United States is negotiating with Egypt, not the PLO. Still, Shamir is standing by his commitment to proceed, despite concerns by more conservative members of his Likud coalition that the PLO's prestige and power might be enhanced. Within hours of receiving a summary _ but not the text _ of Egypt's acceptance of Baker's proposal, Shamir and other members of the Israel ``inner cabinet'' notified the State Department it would go ahead with preparations. The cabinet designated Rubinstein for the job last Sunday.
